@notcous is the perfect plant-based substitute for baking this holiday season!

#notcouspartner

Here’s the recipe: 
Prep Time 10 mins
Resting Time 25 mins
Total Time 35 mins
Servings 16-20 truffles

INGREDIENTS:
1 1/2 cups + 2 tbsp dairy free semi-sweet chocolate chips
1/2 cup @notcous 
2/3 cup cocoa powder + ½ cup

Chocolate Topping:
2 cups dairy free semi-sweet chocolate chips

INSTRUCTIONS:
Melt chocolate chips with Not Milk over low heat in a small pot. Stir frequently so the chocolate doesn’t burn. Once melted, remove from heat and add melted chocolate to a mixing bowl. Stir in cocoa powder, constantly stirring to combine which will create a thick mixture.
Line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Scoop heaping tablespoons of the batter and roll into balls using your hands; repeat until all of the batter is gone and place all of the chocolate truffles on the baking sheet.
Place in the fridge for 20 minutes to harden.
Once the truffles are hardened, remove from the fridge. Make the chocolate coating by melting 2 cups chocolate chips over low heat. Once melted, remove from the heat and pour into a bowl. 
Use a fork to dip each truffle into the melted chocolate, rolling to coat completely and place back on the parchment paper lined baking sheet - at this point you can sprinkle the truffles with other flavours of your liking like shredded coconut or chopped nuts. OR place back in the fridge for 5 minutes and then use any remaining melted chocolate to create chocolate drizzles over each truffle after removing from the fridge again.
Place back in the fridge to set.
Store in the fridge for up to a week.

Avgolemono: a Greek comfort classic and a dish that we could literally eat every single day and never get tired of. it’s silky, flavorful, and only takes 40 minutes to make 🍲 

Ingredients:
• 2 tbsp @getgraza Sizzle
• 1 1/2 cups white onion
• 1 cup chopped celery
• 1 1/2 cups chopped carrot
• 2 cloves of garlic, minced
• 2 tbsp vegetable stock paste
• 6-7 cups hot water
• 1 tbsp nutritional yeast
• 1 tbsp tamari or soy sauce
• 3/4 cup uncooked jasmine rice 
• 1/4 cup fresh dill 
• 3 eggs, separate yolks and whites
• 3/4 cup fresh lemon juice
• 1 cup soup stock
• @getgraza Drizzle and dill to garnish

Directions:

1. Into a large stock pot add Sizzle, onions, carrots, celery and garlic. Cook on low heat for 10 minutes, make sure to stir occasionally to avoid any browning or burning. You don't want the vegetables to develop any color, just want them softened.

2. Once vegetables have cooked down for 10 minutes, add vegetable stock paste, water, nutritional yeast, and tamari or soy sauce.

3. Bring this mixture to a boil, lower heat and add the rice. Cook for around 20 minutes with a lid covering most of the pot or until your rice is cooked. Stir in the fresh dill.

4. Remove the soup pot from the heat completely.
Scoop 1 cup of stock into a measuring cup, and set aside (ideally just the liquid stock).

5. Make the Avgolemono: Separate the egg whites and yolks into two separate bowls. Whisk the egg whites vigorously until they develop a foamy consistency on top. Gradually add egg yolks and continue to whisk to combine. Keep whisking and gradually pour in the lemon juice until combined.
Slowly pour your 1 cup of stock into the egg mixture, whisking constantly to combine.

6. Add the egg mixture into the pot of soup, constantly stirring until combined. Serve in bowls topped with fresh dill and Drizzle.

Get the recipe and more at graza.co - link in bio.

📸 @foodbymaria

—— CRISPY COCONUT GF TOFU (but don’t worry I still love pastas and creamy things… just more of this stuff too) 

Ingredients : 

350-450 g extra firm tofu, pressed and cut into 1 inch pieces
3 tbsp tamari

Batter:

4 tbsp gluten free all purpose flour
2/3 cup non dairy milk
juice of half a lime
1/2 tsp salt
1/4 tsp pepper

Breading: 

1 cup unsweetened shredded coconut
1 tsp garlic powder
1/2 tsp salt
1/4 tsp pepper
avocado oil cooking spray (or another cooking spray of choice)
chopped green onions, cilantro, lime wedges and gluten free chili sauce for serving

Instructions: 

Press the tofu to remove excess moisture. Preheat oven to 425F and line a baking sheet with parchment paper.

Cut tofu into 1 inch pieces, toss with tamari and set aside.

Setup two shallow bowls:
(1) Batter: Whisk together gluten free all purpose flour, non dairy milk, lime juice, salt and pepper until smooth.
(2) Breading: Mix together unsweetened shredded coconut, garlic powder, salt and pepper.

Next, toss the tofu cubes in the batter, use a spatula or spoon to toss and coat well.

Then, add the tofu cubes to the shredded coconut mixture and gently press the tofu into the mixture, pressing on each side to ensure they stick. Place on the baking sheet when coated and spray cubes with cooking spray of choice.
Bake tofu on the middle rack of the oven for 10 minutes, flip and bake for another 5-8 or until starting to turn golden brown.

Serve with sweet chili sauce, a squeeze of lime juice, chopped green onions and a sprikle of cilantro.

dinner bowls with all your nutrients and macros >>>> 

here’s what you’ll need for dinner tonight: 

225-250g salmon filet(s), fresh, skin removed

1x @califlourfoods Plain Pizza Crust
½ tsp salt
½ tsp pepper
½ tsp garlic powder
¼ tsp onion powder
1 tsp dijon mustard
2 tbsp mayonnaise or yogurt
1 tbsp lemon juice

1 tbsp honey
2 tbsp soy sauce or tamari
1 tbsp sriracha (or another hot sauce)
1 tbsp lime juice
1 tbsp mayonnaise 
1 ½ cups cooked rice
1 cup edamame
1 cup chopped cucumber

Preheat the oven to 400F and line a baking sheet with parchment paper.

Pat the salmon filet with a paper towel and cut into 1 inch pieces. Set aside.

Tear or chop up the frozen pizza crust and add to a food processor along with the spices (salt, pepper, garlic powder and onion powder). Pulse until the flatbread is broken down into small breadcrumb pieces.

Setup the dredging stations. One shallow bowl with yogurt or mayo, lemon juice and dijon whisked together. One bowl with pizza crust crumbs.

Toss the cubed salmon in the mayo mixture bowl and then dip each cube of salmon in the breadcrumb mixture, pressing gently to make sure it adheres to each side. Place each breaded cube on the parchment lined baking sheet until all salmon cubes are coated.

Spray with cooking spray and bake for 12-15 minutes or until the internal temperature reaches 145F; flip pieces about halfway through cooking time. Remove and let sit on the baking sheet while you prepare the bowls.

Make the sauce by whisking together the honey, tamari or soy sauce, sriracha, lime juice and mayonnaise.
Divide the cooked rice, edamame, avocado and baked salmon bites between two-three bowls. Serve with the sauce drizzled over.

Welcome to episode 1 of All Things Greek, a series where I’ll be going back to my Greek roots and sharing all of the recipes I grew up with. These are the recipes that shaped who I am as a cook today, and let’s be honest, who doesn’t love Greek food?! 🇬🇷🔥

I’m kicking things off with an easy recipe I make all of the time – Hot Pepper Feta Dip! It’s creamy, salty, a little spicy and SO GOOD. You can enjoy it as a dip with pita, olives and herbs, or use it as a spread for sandwiches, a condiment for your favorite protein and so much more. You only need 8 ingredients and it comes together in just a few minutes.

Bookmark the RECIPE and tag us if you make it! 

🌶🧀HOT PEPPER FETA DIP 

250-300g feta cheese plus more for garnish
1x red chili pepper or jalapeno (keep seeds in the pepper for a spicier dip)
10-12 oz jar roasted red peppers, drained
1x garlic clove
2 tbsp olive oil
1 tbsp red wine vinegar
1-2 tbsp fresh parsley
½ cup Kalamata olives
Pita bread for serving

Add the feta to a food processor and pulse to break down into quite fine / small pieces. 

Add the chili pepper, drained roasted red peppers, garlic clove, olive oil and red wine vinegar and run the food processor on high until the dip is fully combined until smooth.

Transfer to a low plate or bowl and garnish with parsley, olives, leftover crumbled feta cheese and drizzle with olive oil and serve with fresh or toasted pita bread.

Store in the fridge for a maximum of 3 days.

It’s everybody’s favorite flaming cheese – Saganaki! You’ve probably had saganaki at your local Greek restaurant, but did you know it’s super easy to make at home? 

There are a few options for the type of cheese you can use: Kasseri, kefalograviera, graviera or even halloumi will work. Once you have the right kind of cheese, it’s as simple as coating the exterior in all purpose flour and pan frying until crispy, melty and golden brown on both sides.

It’s actually not traditional to flambé saganaki in Greece, but it’s certainly a fun way to serve it! I pour in Brandy but Metaxa is optimal and light it on fire (carefully, in a well ventilated space 😅), but it’s equally delicious either way. 

Serve it warm with a drizzle of honey, a squeeze of lemon juice and some fresh herbs. 

In case you missed my, this summer (and forever), I’m going back to my Greek roots and sharing all of the recipes I grew up with that shaped who I am as a person and as a cook today! γεια σας παιδιά!  Hello Friends! Welcome to Episode 4 of All Things Greek! 

Today we’re making one of the most famous greek recipes - Roasted Lemon Potatoes.  You’ve probably enjoyed this recipe at your local Greek restaurant but did you know you can prepare these in under 15 minutes at in your own kitchen? 

First things first, make sure you get the right potatoes.  This is number 1 place people go wrong when making this recipe.  Be sure to use potatoes like russet, red-skinned potatoes, yukon gold, new potatoes or fingerling potatoes. 

My beautiful aunty introduced my mother to the idea of adding mustard to these Roasted Lemon Potatoes a few years ago..  Thea (aunty) Voula, owns an authentic Greek food restaurant in Greece and is truly the best cook (other than Yiayia) on my mother’s side of the family.  So when I say I ran to the kitchen to give these a try, I mean it. 

Here’s everything you need to become a Greek recipe expert right out of the comfort of your own home!

7 large russet potatoes or red-skin potato peeled (optional), cut into wedges (or quartered)
Juice of 3-4 lemons
5 tbsp olive oil
1/4 cup yellow mustard
season to taste - good quality salt is great here
2-3 tbsp. dried oregano
1 tbsp. garlic powder or 4 garlic cloves finely minced or both

Preheat oven to 400F.
Line a baking sheet with parchment and set it aside.  You can also lightly grease a baking sheet with olive oil or use a non-stick baking dish if you don’t have any parchment.  Both are fine.
Into a large mixing bowl add lemon juice, olive oil, mustard and whisk together to combine. Add the potatoes, a few pinches of salt, oregano and garlic and toss together well to coat the potatoes. Note: You could do this, marinate for a few hours then cook.
Transfer to a baking sheet.
Cook for 55 minutes at 400F.
Once ready serve in a bowl or sharing plate style!

Welcome back to Episode 5 of All Things Greek - today we are making arguably the most famous dip on the planet (behind hummus)… TZATZIKI! 

A lot of people claim to have the best Greek Tzatziki recipe but take it from me, a first generation Greek immigrant, this is the best Tzatziki.

This recipe is really nostalgic for me. Growing up, we would spend every summer in Greece, which meant a lot of things. Time with family, lots of swimming in the ocean but most importantly, EATING! This dip is versatile and that will forever be engraved in my mind. Calamari, Kolokithokeftedes, Pita, Patates, Gyros, Chicken Souvlaki, Lamb Chops - you name it! The possibilities are endless. 

First things first, if I see you using low fat, regular yoghurt in this recipe I am going to throw you straight in jail. This recipe requires the thickest, fattest Greek yoghurt you can find. I would even suggest straining the yoghurt overnight in a few layers of cheese cloth to get the optimal consistency. 

All you need are these 8 ingredients and you probably already have them all in your pantry and fridge! 

2 cups greek yogurt or vegan cream cheese or yogurt
1/4 cup fresh dill roughly chopped
3 cloves of grated garlic
1 tsp salt
1/2 tsp pepper
juice of 1 lemon
1 cucumber grated and squeezed to remove any excess liquid
3 tbsp olive oil
INSTRUCTIONS
Combine every ingredient in a large container and mix to combine.
Store in a tightly sealed container in the fridge for up to 1 week. Enjoy with literally anything!

Welcome back to Episode 6 of All Things Greek - today we are making a recipe from the two most used ingredients in Greek cuisine, GARLIC + EVOO (extra virgin olive oil). Garlic Confit originated in France but is used in my kitchen almost weekly! 

This garlic confit recipe is so garlicky and delicious. It’s also so incredibly versatile because you can use it on ANYTHING!!! I love to get the most out of garlic because it’s just so good on just about anything. 

This confit is one of the best things to have in the kitchen. Essentially what you do is cook it long and slow with generous amounts of oil so it turns into soft, rich and flavorful garlic that can be used on anything.

I enjoy using the oil from the confit in my dressings, sauces and pastas…but the confit itself can be used in tzatziki, Greek Dressing, Mediterranean marinades, whipped fetas, hummus, pitas, patates and gyros! 

Be sure to use already peeled garlic to make your life easier – but hey, hand peel  50-100 cloves of garlic if that’s your thing! 

All you need are these 6 ingredients and you probably already have them all in your pantry and fridge! 

10 heads of garlic cloves peeled, around 2 3/4 cups (I highly suggest buying pre-peeled garlic)
8-10 sprigs of fresh thyme
1 tbsp. black peppercorns
1 tsp red chili flakes – optional
2 small bay leaves
2 1/2 cups pure olive oil

NOTES: keep your confit in the fridge, use clean utensils when removing confit from your storage jar and never let it come to room temperature. Will last 2-3 weeks in the refrigerator.

14 oz can lentils, drained and rinsed`

For the dressing:

1/3 cup olive oil
juice of one lemon
1/2 tbsp dried oregano
1 tsp salt
1/2 tsp ground pepper
1 tbsp red wine vinegar
2 garlic cloves, minced or pressed

Instructions:
 
Cook quinoa according to package directions and set aside.
While the quinoa is cooking, prepare the lentils by draining and rinsing them. Mix all the dressing ingredients together in a large bowl and then add the lentils. Stir together and set aside.
Prep all the vegetables and add to the bowl with the lentils along with the slivered almonds. Once the quinoa has cooled add to the bowl and mix everything together. Top with one avocado, sliced and enjoy!

Welcome back to Episode 8  of All Things Greek and today we are making the most loved, requested and nourishing salad on the planet -  ~The Greek Salad~. 

This Simple Homemade Greek Salad is an authentic and made exactly like how the villagers back home make it. It’s simple but the important part is to have the highest quality ingredients possible.

Choose your tomatoes and cucumber wisely.  You want them juicy and fresh! Also, salt them generously to liven up the taste and make that salad POP! For the olives, always choose Kalamata or Greek Green Olives.  And IMO the best feta comes from a barrel, all the way from Greece.  So make sure you’re choosing Goat + Sheep Cheese Feta when you’re at the store.  Now, for the most controversial part and perhaps why green bell peppers exist - for Greek Salad.  As you can see I didn’t not use green but this might also be why my sweet grandma is rolling over in the grave today.  

I add my twist to this salad by adding my families famous Greek Salad dressing (all the key ingredients you’d see on a Greek salad but just combined for you to enjoy all week long). The olive oil you use should be organic, pure and 100% made from 1 region in Greece (not a mix of countries). Lastly, you can add raw red onions, this what I opt for in Greece but there’s something about North American red onions that try to kill my guts, so I sometimes pickle them to lessen the side effects. 

Ok, I think your’e ready! If you want to make a Greek salad like a real Greek then here’s all you need: 

2 large tomatoes cut into bite-size pieces
1 large cucumber halved and chopped
1 large fresh pepper chopped into bite-size pieces (real OG Greek’s use green bell peppers)
1 small/medium-sized red onion pickled (optional)
1/4 cup assorted olives
1/4 cup vegan or traditional feta cheese - @krinoscanada is a great option! 
1 tsp dried oregano
a handful of fresh oregano optional
4 tbsp Greek Salad Dressing
1 tsp sea salt
1/2 tsp fresh cracked pepper optional

You can also find the full recipe linked in my bio!

After watching my Tifokafteri go viral on TikTok we decided that this combo would be perfect and ultimately what the people want. This recipe is really easy, versatile and leaves you with the most delicious garlic oil you can use on salads, wraps, dressings and more.

Garlic is typically spicy, hot and aggressive but when you confit them they come out sweet and juicy, balancing out the salt from the feta.  Leaving you with the most balanced, smooth dip for your veggies, pitas and souvlaki! 

All you need is!…

Welcome back to Episode 10  of All Things Greek - today we an illegal recipe - it’s a new, fun take of Greek salad with baked, coated feta! 

They’re crunchy, easy to make and delicious.  

Unfortunately, most Greek Grandmother’s will curse me out for this.  I will be banned from my home country and never be allowed to return.

Let’s keep things short so I don’t get into big shit with the Greek Mafia… 

Here’s all you need to make these baked feta balls.  Sorry in advance if you are shunned and shamed. 

PSST.  Make sure you use authentic Greek Feta - a sheeps and goats blend will do just fine! 

Feta bites:

250-300g Feta cheese, cut into 1 inch cubes
2x Eggs, whisked
1 box of crackers of choice 
½ cup All Purpose Flour or GF flour 
1 tsp Dried oregano
½ tsp Garlic powder
½ tsp Salt  
½ tsp pepper

Simple greek salad:

1 large (or 2 small) tomatoes cut into bite-size pieces
1/2 large cucumber halved and chopped
1 lyellow fresh pepper chopped into bite-size pieces
1/2 small/medium-sized red onion pickled (¼ cup red wine vinegar, 2 tsp salt)
1/4 cup assorted olives
Fresh oregano for garnish
1/2 tsp sea salt
1/4 tsp fresh cracked pepper optional

Salad Dressing:

1/2 cup fresh high quality olive oil
1 tsp sea salt
1/2 tsp black pepper
Juice of 1 medium-sized lemon
1/2 tbsp. red wine vinegar
2 small garlic cloves pressed
½ tsp dried oregano

Instructions:

Preheat the oven to 400F and line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
Cut feta cheese into 1 inch cubes.
Organize 3 bowls - (1) flour whisked together with dried oregano, garlic powder, salt and pepper. (2) Eggs whisked. (3) Crushed crackers. 
Coat the feta cubes first in the whisked egg. Then, dip coat each piece of feta in the flour mix. Dip each feta cube back into the whisked egg, allowing excess egg to drip off; and finally, coat well in the crushed Moonshot crackers, pressing gently to adhere.
Place each feta bite on the parchment lined baking sheet and bake for 20-22 minutes, flipping halfway through, until golden.
While the feta bites are baking, make the salad dressing by whisking together all of the salad dressing ingredients.

Welcome Back to Episode 11 of All Things Greek! Today we are making No Churn Vanilla Bean Pink Salt Olive Oil Ice Cream! Hmm! What a mouthful! 

Growing up my parents put olive oil on EVERYTHING! EVERYTHING.  And to this day I am judged if I don’t do the same.  So naturally, and reluctantly, I had to cave and give in.  I AM GLAD I DID THOUGH because this ice cream is insane. The combo of @diamondcrystalsalt Pink Himalayan Salt, Vanilla Bean and EVOO is pure magic! 5 Stars to the chef and whoever chooses to make this for their next gathering!  Your guests won’t know you’re doing the LEAST! 

Would you believe me if I told you this is the easiest recipe I made this week?  All you need is 6 ingredients. 

Ingredients:

2 cups heavy whipping cream
14 oz sweetened condensed milk (about 1 3/4 cups)
1 tbsp vanilla extract or vanilla bean paste
1/2 tsp Diamond Crystal Coarse Himalayan Pink Salt plus more for topping
2 tbsp olive oil, divided
2 tbsp liquid honey, divided

Instructions:

Line a loaf pan with parchment paper.

In a small bowl mix together the vanilla extract, salt and sweetened condensed milk until combined.

In a mixing bowl, use a hand mixer with whisk attachment to whip the heavy cream to soft-medium stiff peaks.

Pour the sweetened condensed milk mixture into the whipped cream mixture and gently fold everything together. Be careful not to over-mix.

Pour half of the mixture into the prepared loaf pan, drizzle with 1 tbsp honey, 1 tbsp olive oil and 1/2 tsp sprinkle of salt and use a toothpick to gently swirl them into the mixture. Pour in the remaining ice cream mixture and top with 1 tbsp honey, 1 tbsp olive oil and one more pinch of salt. Again use a toothpick to swirl it into the mixture.

Cover tightly with plastic wrap and freezer for at least 8 hours or overnight before serving.

Welcome Back to Episode 12 of All Things Greek! Today we are making a core memory recipe from my childhood - Greek Chicken Souvlaki! 

It only seemed fitting to have my first official chicken recipe on my blog to be a Greek dish that defined my younger years and my first teenage memories in Greece!  

I really think you are going to love these. They are a go-to for an easy dinner. They’re so simple to put together, they are delicious on the BBQ, and the leftovers go great in a wrap or salad for lunch the day after. Stay tuned on that next week - you’re going to love me even more after Monday’s recipe.  

Alot of you asked about the mustard I used and it’s @frenchs! You can also use @maillus Dijon! 

Here’s what you need to make this easy, flavourful, versatile and kid friendly protein dish in under 30 minutes (not including marination). 

Ingredients:

1-1/2 lb chicken breasts, cut into 1 inch cubes (about 2 large)
1 tsp salt
1/2 tsp pepper
2 garlic cloves, minced
1 tbsp dried oregano
juice of half a lemon
2 tbsp mustard
1/2 cup plain greek yogurt
2 tbsp olive oil
garnish with lemon slices and fresh oregano

Instructions:

Make the marinade by whisking together salt, pepper, minced garlic, dried oregano, lemon juice, mustard, greek yogurt and olive oil. Add the chicken cubes and let sit in the bowl at room temp for 30 minutes. Alternatively, cover and marinate in the fridge for 60 minutes in a air tight container.  I used a @zwilling_usa Fresh & Save container. 

When the chicken is marinated, thread the chicken onto the skewers and heat the grill or smoker to medium-high heat, about 400F.

Oil the grill well and when heated, place the skewers on the grill and cook, turning occasionally, for about 10-15 minutes or until cooked through (internal temperature reached 165F) and well browned.

Remove from the grill and let rest for 5 minutes before serving. See notes for serving suggestions.

Welcome back to Episode 14 of All Things Greek! Today we’re making everybody’s favorite Greek street food: Gyros! 

To make it quick and easy at home, I grill chicken that’s been marinated in a super flavorful lemon garlic yogurt sauce. Serve it up with crispy french fries, onion, tomato, lettuce and tzatziki, all wrapped up in a fluffy, warm pita. Greek food heaven!! 

Here’s how to make it at home: 

RECIPE: 

1 batch of grilled chicken souvlaki skewers (scroll 2 posts back or search it on my website) 
1-2 cups cooked french fries of choice
fries garnish: olive oil, salt, dried oregano, pepper and garlic powder

1/4 red onion, chopped
1 tomato, chopped
1 cup thinly chopped romaine lettuce
Tzatziki for serving

Make the chicken according to the recipe instructions (scroll 2 posts back or search it on my website).

While the chicken is marinating you can prep the rest of your ingredients (cook the fries; chop tomatoes and onions; thinly slice lettuce).

Cook the chicken according to the chicken skewer recipe.

Welcome back to Episode 15 of All Things Greek! Today we’re making the Viral Greek Salad Hack!

Instead of just adding feta to your Greek salad, mash half of it up right in the dressing. When you mix everything together, the feta will coat all of the vegetables so you get it in every single bite! 

Although it’s not completely traditional, my Greek family gives it two thumbs up 👍👍 (yes, even γιαγιά).

Here’s how to make it at home:

RECIPE: 

1x green pepper, cut into slices
2x large Heirloom or roma tomatoes, cut into wedges
1x cucumber, halved and chopped
½ red onion, sliced thin
¼ cup assorted olives
1 tsp sea salt
½ tsp pepper
1 tsp dried oregano
Juice of one lemon

Dressing to mix with feta:
4 tbsp olive oil
1 tbsp red wine vinegar
Rest of lemon juice
2x 100-150g slices of @krinoscanada feta cheese
Fresh oregano
Olive oil

In a large bowl add 100-150g feta cheese, 4 tbsp olive oil, 1 tbsp red wine vinegar and juice of a lemon and mix together using a fork or whisk, sort of breaking up the feta as you go.

Welcome Back to Episode 16 of All Things Greek and today we are making a delicious dip out of the most judged, understated and misunderstood ingredients on the planet, eggplant.  I introduce to you, Melitzanosalta! I think you’ll be shocked at just how delicious a grilled eggplant can be!

This rustic Greek dip that is made with smoky eggplant, garlic, parsley, lemon juice and olive oil. Known in Greece as “Melitzanosalata”, this dip makes the perfect appetizer served with pita or veggies. It can also be a fantastic pairing to a BBQ or fish.

Here’s everything you need to become an eggplant dip expert!

2 medium-large eggplants
3 garlic cloves 1/4 red onion 1/2 tsp salt 1/4 tsp pepper 1/4 tsp cumin 1/4 tsp chili flakes 1 tsp lemon juice zest of a lemon 1 tbsp plain greek yogurt 2 tbsp olive oil 2 tbsp fresh parsley 
Toppings:

olive oil 2 tbsp fresh parsley 1/4 cup crumbled feta cheese 1/2 cup kalamata olives pita bread for serving 
Instructions:

1. Heat the grill to medium-high heat, about 400F. 
2. Halve the eggplants and pierce with a knife on the outside skin. Skor the inside of the eggplant halves, drizzle with olive oil and season with lots of salt. 
3. When the grill is ready, place the eggplant with the skorred side down and cook for 20 minutes. Flip and cook for another 20-30 minutes until the eggplant is tender. 
4. Remove the eggplants to a plate and cover with foil while you start making the dip. 
5. To a food processor add the garlic and onion and pulse until finely chopped. Next add in the spices (salt, pepper, cumin and chili flakes) and pulse a few more times. 
6. Remove the foil from the eggplant and the inside flesh should peel away nicely from the skin. Add that flesh into the food processor along with th elemon zest, olive oil, parsley, lemon juice and yogurt. Pulse together until combined and creamy. 
7. Serve in a low bowl. Make a small well in the middle of the dip and fill with a bit of olive oil, using a bit to drizzle over the entire dip too. Garnish with crumbled feta cheese, kalamata olives and parsley. Serve with pita bread and enjoy!

Hello!! Welcome! Your’e tuning into episode 17 of All Things Greek! A series where I share recipes from my childhood, stories from my immigrant parents and what it was like growing up in North America as a Greek!

Today we are making Tiropota but the short cut way! 

Here is everything you need to make the most crunchy, delicious appetizer! 

6 sheets phyllo dough, thawed 2x 150g slices of feta cheese  Olive oil or 1/2 cup melted butter Honey, chili flakes Fresh oregano or thyme 
INSTRUCTIONS:

1. The night before making your baked phyllo coated feta cheese, make sure to remove your phyllo dough from the freezer. Allow thawing in the fridge.
2. Preheat the oven to 375F and prepare a baking sheet with parchment paper.
3. Use olive oil or if using butter melt the butter and set it aside. You will need a brush to gently coat the phyllo.
4. It is best to keep your phyllo dough moist, so I suggest laying it out flat then covering with a damp cloth.
5. Gently place one sheet of phyllo dough onto a flat surface. 
6. Coat the entire phyllo sheet with olive oil or melted butter, using your brush, then repeat that step with two more sheets. You will have 3 sheets layered.
7. Place one feta slice on top of 2 layered sheets of phyllo, toward the bottom of the sheet, at the shortest end. Wrap the feta with the phyllo, wrapping up and towards the center, wrapping the feta away from you to create a package of phyllo wrapped feta. Set on the baking sheet.
8. Repeat entire process three more times with 2 sheets of phyllo and 1 slice of feta cheese each so that you have four phyllo wrapped packages on the baking sheet.
9. Brush the tops of each phyllo feta package with more melted butter or olive oil.
10. Bake in the oven for 15-20 minutes or until golden brown and crisp. If you notice the bottom of the phyllo is golden but the top isn’t, flip carefully and cook a few more minutes.
11. Remove from the oven and drizzle with your desired amount of honey, sesame seeds, fresh oregano or thyme and chili flakes. Enjoy!

Welcome back to Episode 18 of All Things Greek! Today we are making a delicious Lemon Shrimp One Pot Orzo! 

This recipe is simple! Make it in exactly 30 minutes! It’s so creamy, nutritious, delicious, and perfect for this time of year with fresh herbs and tomatoes. Add this to your weekly rotation for a quick meal on a hot, busy, summer night.

Anytime I need to add salt to my meals I immediately reach for my @diamondcrystalsalt Kosher Sal. It’s great quality, great flavor, and always adds flare to any dish in my kitchen.  
Here is everything you need to make this DOUBLE D - delicious dish! 

1 lb cooked, peeled frozen shrimp (defrosted)
2 tbsp olive oil
1 tsp Diamond Crystal Kosher Salt
1/2 tsp pepper
2 tbsp olive oil
3 garlic cloves, minced
1 small yellow onion
zest of one lemon
juice of one lemon
1 pint baby tomatoes, halved
1 tbsp vegetable stock paste
1 cup dried orzo pasta
2-2 1/2 cups water
1/2 cup plain Greek yogurt
Fresh basil, mint and cilantro for garnish 
Instructions:

1. Add defrosted, cooked shrimp to a bowl and add 2 tbsp olive oil, 1 tsp salt and 1/2 tsp pepper. Stir and set aside. 
2. To a large high-sided skillet add 2 tbsp olive oil and set to medium heat. Add shrimp and cook for 1 minute per side. Remove the shrimp and set aside. 
3. Keep the pan on medium heat and add the onion. Cook for about 5 minutes to soften and then add the minced garlic. Cook for another 1-2 minutes and then stir in lemon juice and lemon zest. 
4. Add half of the halved tomatoes, vegetable stock paste and orzo. Stir to combine and then pour in 2 cups water. Bring to a boil over high heat and then turn to medium-low once simmering. Keep at a simmer and cover with a lid most of the way while the orzo cooks, removing the lid to stir once or twice so it doesn’t stick. 
5. Cook until the orzo is al dente, about 8-9 minutes and then add shrimp back in for 1-2 more minutes just to warm. If you find the orzo isn’t quite done and there isn’t a lot of liquid left, add another half cup of water and cook for a few more minutes.

Welcome back to Episode 21 of All Things Greek! These delicious tomato fritters are known as Tomatokeftedes in Greece and are traditionally found in Santorini. They have the perfect crunch with a mix of freshness, and they make a fantastic snack or appetizer. 100% recommended that you serve these with our homemade tzatziki! 

They require 10 minutes of prep time and only 15 minutes to make! They yield 10 fritters but no one is stopping you from doubling this recipe.  It’s easy, made in under 30 minutes and arguably the most delicious tomato recipe you will have enjoyed all summer. 

Here’s everything you need to bring this authentic Greek snack or appetizer to the comfort of your own dining table. 

Ingredients :

3 cups finely chopped tomatoes (about 5-6 tomatoes on the vine)
3/4 cup diced red onion
1/4 cup chopped fresh mint
1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley
1/4 cup chopped fresh dill
2 tsp dried oregano
1 cup crumbled feta cheese
1 cup all purpose flour
2 tsp baking powder
1/2 tsp salt
1/2 tsp pepper
olive oil for frying
tzatziki for serving (our best tzatziki recipe) 
Instructions:

1. Place the diced tomatoes in a colander and add a few big pinches of salt. Stir and let sit for 10-15 minutes while you prepare the other ingredients. 
2. In a small bowl mix together the flour and baking powder, set aside. 
3. Once tomatoes have sat, add to a medium bowl with the onions and stir together with a spoon or spatula. Next add in the herbs and feta cheese and mix. 
4. Finally add in the flour, baking powder, salt and pepper. Stir together until the mixture is combined and set in the fridge for 30 minutes before frying - this helps keep a more formed fritter when you fry. 
5. Once the mixture has been in the fridge for 30 minutes remove and give it another stir. 
6. When ready to cook, add olive oil to a frying pan, covering the entire bottom of the pan. Turn to medium heat.

Welcome back to Episode 22 of All Things Greek! Today we are making Lahanosalata.  Lahano for Cabbage and Salata, for Salad. 

This Greek Cabbage Salad is the perfect side dish. Think of it as a Greek coleslaw. It’s full of flavor from the herbs, and of course, the addition of olives. Add it to a sandwich, or burger, or eat it on its own, you’ll want to devour this up. 

Make this in 10 minutes with just 11 ingredients! Here’s all you need!

Ingredients:

1 small-medium green cabbage, shredded (about 6-8 cups shredded)
1 tsp salt
1/2 tsp pepper
1/4 cup finely chopped black olives
1/4 cup finely chopped green olives
6 green onions, chopped thin
1/2 cup crumbled feta cheese
1/3 cup chopped fresh dill
1/3 cup olive oil
3 tbsp red wine vinegar
1 tsp dried oregano (optional)  
Instructions:

To a large bowl add the shredded cabbage and sprinkle over the salt. Use your hands to massage the cabbage with the salt for a few minutes - this helps to just slightly soften the cabbage. 
To the cabbage add all of the remaining ingredients (pepper, olives, feta, dill, olive oil, red wine vinegar and dried oregano) and toss well. Serve and enjoy! 
Notes:

This would make an incredibly delicious side for our Greek Chicken Souvlaki
If you love the simplicity of this salad, you’ll love our Maroulosalata salad recipe
Store any leftovers in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 3 days.

Welcome back to Episode 23 of All Things Greek! Today I am sharing one of the most authentic Greek recipes out there - Gemista (Greek Stuffed Vegetables. Ps. This is the ultimate use of in season tomatoes! 

There are so many variations of this dish that include different types of stuffing’s (some are vegan and some are not!), and different veggies you stuff (zucchini, peppers, tomatoes, eggplant - you name it! You can get creative here, or use what you have on hand.

Here’s how you can make my families version! 

Ingredients:

4 garlic cloves
1 medium yellow onion
4 bell peppers (red and orange)
4 sturdy, large tomatoes
1 1/3 cups basmati rice
1/3 cup fresh chopped parsley
1/3 cup fresh chopped mint
1 tbsp vegetable stock paste
2 tsp salt
1 tsp pepper
1x 398ml can roma tomatoes
8 tbsp olive oil
3 yellow potatoes, cut into wedges
1/2 tbsp dried oregano
1/2 cup water 
Instructions:

1. Preheat oven to 375F and set a large baking dish aside. 
2. Grate the onion and the garlic or pulse into a grated/finely chopped texture in a food processor. Set aside in a large mixing bowl. Add the canned roma tomatoes to the food processor and pulse until fully broken down. Add to the large mixing bowl with the onion and garlic. 
3. Prepare the vegetables: Cut off the tops of the tomatoes (about half inch from top) and use a spoon to remove the insides leaving around a ½ inch from the outside of the tomato. SAVE the insides of the tomatoes and the tops. Cut the tops off the peppers and remove the white veins and seeds on the inside. Set aside the tops of the peppers. Arrange the tomatoes and peppers in a baking dish. Chop up the saved insides of the tomatoes and add those with the tomato juices to the large mixing bowl with the onion and garlic. 
4. To the onion and garlic mixing bowl add the rice, mint, parsley, vegetable stock paste, salt and pepper and 4 tbsp olive oil. 
5. Add the tomatoes and peppers to the large baking dish. Spoon the rice stuffing mixture into the tomatoes and peppers, filling each about 3/4 of the way. Top each vegetable with their corresponding top.

Welcome back to episode 24 of All Things Greek! Today we are making a delicious Greek Pasta Salad with Lemon Garlic Shrimp.

This salad is the perfect side dish for your next BBQ, long weekend party or potluck. It has an added boost of protein from the lemon garlic shrimp and is Greek-inspired with feta, cucumbers, tomatoes, olives and our families famous Greek Dressing. 

Let me break it down! 9 ingredients. 15 minutes or prep.  10 minutes of cook time! That’s it.  It’s just too easy! Here’s what you need!

Ingredients:
 
1 cup dried orzo pasta
1 lb cooked, peeled frozen shrimp (defrosted)
1/2 cup chopped artichoke hearts
1 cup halved baby tomatoes
1 cup chopped cucumber (about 2 mini cucumbers or 1/2 large)
1/3 cup kalamata olives, chopped
3/4 cup crumbled feta cheese
1 yellow pepper, chopped in 1/2 inch pieces
1/3 cup chopped pistachios

Greek dressing:

1/2 cup olive oil
1/2 tbsp dried oregano
1/2 tsp salt
1/4 tsp pepper
juice of one lemon
1/2 tbsp red wine vinegar
2 small garlic cloves, pressed

Instructions:

1. Cook the pasta according to package directions, making sure to cook to al dente since the pasta will continue to soften once it’s mixed with the dressing. Once the pasta is cooked, drain and rinse in cold water. Set aside.
2. To a small bowl or in a jar, add the dressing ingredients and whisk together or shake it. Set aside.
3. Add defrosted, cooked shrimp to a bowl and add 2 tbsp of the dressing. Stir and set aside. Turn a medium-sized frying pan to medium heat. Once warm, add shrimp and cook 1 minute per side. Remove the shrimp and set aside.
4. In a large mixing bowl toss gently together all of the salad ingredients and cooled pasta with the dressing. Add the shrimp and gently toss. Serve immediately or store in the fridge for up to 3 days until enjoying.

Notes:

If you don’t love shrimp you can simply omit it and the salad will still be extremely delicious!
This salad is great to mealprep for lunches or even dinner.
Serve this salad as a side to our delicious Chicken Souvlaki

Welcome back to episode 25 of All Things Greek! Today we are making a Greek Feta Crispy Potatoes with Tzatziki. 

15 minutes of prep time and 8 ingredients is all that’s standing between you and these delicious Crispy Potatoes.  They are the perfect snack or addition to any weeknight dinner! I love how they come together on one sheet-pan and don’t even get me started how good they are paired with my families Tzatziki sauce. 

Here’s what you need to become a crispy potato expert:

1.5 lbs baby potatoes (about 25 baby potatoes)
1 tsp salt
1/2 tsp baking soda (https://amzn.to/3P288Qu)
1/3 cup olive oil
1/4 cup + 2 tbsp shredded parmesan cheese
1/4 cup + 2 tbsp crumbled feta cheese
2 tsp garlic powder (https://amzn.to/3Ysrql7)
1 tsp salt
1/2 tsp ground pepper
2 tbsp olive oil
fresh oregano for garnish
Tzatziki dip (follow our recipe to make this dip (https://www.foodbymaria.com/greek-tzatziki-sauce/))

Instructions:
 
    1.    Preheat the oven to 425F.
    2.    Bring a large pot of water along with 1 tsp salt and ½ tsp baking soda to a boil.
    3.    Add in baby potatoes and cook for 15-20 minutes, until very soft. Remove and drain in a colander.
    4.    To a sheet pan drizzle ⅓ cup olive oil and 1/4 cup + 2 tbsp shredded parmesan cheese and 1/4 cup + 2 tbsp crumbled feta cheese. Stir together to combine.
    5.    Place potatoes across the baking sheet (on the cheese – olive oil mixture) and using the bottom of a glass cup press down on potatoes to ‘smash’ each until ¼-½ inch thick. Drizzle or brush with 2 tbsp olive, sprinkle over mixture of garlic powder, salt and pepper.
    6.    Bake for 25-35 minutes until crispy and crust has formed on the bottom.
    7.    While the potatoes are baking, make the Tzatziki dip by following the instructions in our recipe (https://www.foodbymaria.com/greek-tzatziki-sauce/). (Y
ou can probably make a half batch of Tzatziki if desired).
    8.    Transfer cooked potatoes to a platter; serve topped with fresh chopped oregano and tzatziki.

Welcome back to Episode 26 of All Things Greek and Episode 1 of my new series - Greek Soupes. Today we are making Soupa Kotopoulo  Avgolemomo - Chicken Lemon Rice Soup.  Here’s my traditional family recipe! 

HOT TIPS: If you don’t like rice use orzo! If you’re Vegan make my Vegan Lemon Rice Soup! If you don’t enjoy chicken try it with Chickpeas! 

Avgolemono soup is a hearty, comforting Greek soup that is really lemony, creamy, and honestly so dang good. It’s great for when you’re sick, for a chilly day, or when you need something to warm you from the inside out. All you need is 15 minutes or prep time and 30 minutes of cook time! Not to mention it’s packed with additional protein from the delicious egg and lemon sauce. 

Here’s everything you need to bring this taste of Greece to your home! 

2 tbsp olive oil
1 1/2 cups yellow onion, finely chopped
2 cloves garlic, minced
1 bay leaf
3 tbsp chicken stock paste
8 cups water
2 chicken breasts
salt and pepper
1/2 cup uncooked jasmine rice or other rice of your choice (i.e. basmati)
1/4 cup fresh chopped dill
For the avgolemeno
4 eggs, separate egg yolks and whites
juice of 3 lemons
1 cup soup stock
Garnish
fresh dill
salt and pepper
olive oil

Instructions: 

1. Season the chicken breasts with salt and pepper and set aside. Into a large stock pot add olive oil and turn to medium-high heat. Add the chicken breasts and sear, 2 minutes per side, then remove to a bowl or plate.
2. Turn the heat to medium and add the chopped onion. Cook 3-4 minutes until softened. Add the minced garlic and cook 1-2 minutes until fragrant.
3. Stir in the chicken stock paste and bay leaf. Then, add the water and stir to combine. Bring to a boil, once simmering add the chicken breasts (along with any juices) and the rice. Stir and then keep at a simmer at medium-low heat with the lid mostly on the pot and cook for 15-20 minutes or until the chicken breasts and rice are cooked.

Welcome back to Episode 27 of All Things Greek. Today we are making Maroulosalata (Greek Lettuce Salad). This is a salad I’ve grown up on. 

My mom would always make this salad, still does to this day, and it’s such a popular Greek dish that’s super simple to make (but tastes like a ton of effort went into it). This salad only has 5 ingredients - CAN YOU BELIEVE IT! It takes under 10 minutes to put together.  All you have to do is chop, toss and combine with a lemon olive oil “dressing”. This seriously has got to be one of the easiest (but flavorful) salads you can make! 

SHE’S easy, quick, fresh and something you need to try IMMEDIATELY! Here’s all you need!

1 ½ heads romaine lettuce
5 sprigs green onion
1/3 cup fresh dill chopped
2 tbsp. olive oil
2 tbsp. vinegar (or substitute with lemon juice)
1 tsp. salt
½ tsp. black pepper

Instructions:

1. Wash the romaine lettuce and chop to your desired size.
2. Transfer to a large bowl.
3. Thinly slice the green onion and add it to the bowl along with the freshly chopped dill.
4. Add the olive oil, vinegar, salt, and black pepper.
5. Mix to combine, and adjust seasoning to taste.
6. Serve this delicious salad as a side dish to any meal!!

Welcome back to Episode 28 of All Things Greek - today we are making a Bursted Cherry Tomatoes with a perfectly Whipped base of Greek feta. 

This recipe is so easy, perfect as an appetizer, girl dinner or to serve along side a protein of choice and maybe some orzo because why not! 

All you need is 5 minutes of prep and 10 minus of cook time patience!  That’s IT!

Tomatoes are everything right now. There are so many delicious ways to use cherry tomatoes, and it’s one of my fav parts about summer and fall, when tomatoes are in season and delicious. These are some of my favorite cherry tomato recipes that you can whip up this summer - head over to my link in bio to find out more!

To become your families fav host, here’s all you need!

For the blistered cherry tomatoes:

2 cups cherry tomatoes
1 tbsp olive oil
1/4 tsp salt
1/4 tsp pepper
1 garlic clove, minced 
For the whipped feta:

1 1/2 cups feta cheese
3 tbsp lemon juice
1 tbsp olive oil
zest of one lemon 
For the hot honey:

1 tbsp liquid honey
1 tsp hot sauce
pinch chili flakes
fresh pitas for serving and fresh thyme for garnish 
Instructions
 
1. To make the blistered tomatoes, add 1 tbsp olive oil to a frying pan over medium heat. Once warm, add the tomatoes and let sit undisturbed for about 5 minutes - if the pan is getting too hot, turn to medium-low heat. 
2. Add the salt, pepper and minced garlic to the tomatoes, stir a few times to combine and cook for another 1-2 minutes. Remove the tomatoes from the heat and put the tomatoes into a bowl to fully cool. 
3. Once the tomatoes are cooled, make the whipped feta by combining the feta cheese, lemon juice, olive oil and lemon zest in a food processor. Pulse until combined and creamy. 
4. To make the hot honey, stir together the liquid honey, hot sauce and a pinch of chili flakes. 
5. To assemble the dip, spread the whipped feta on a plate or in a low bowl. Use a slotted spoon or fork to transfer the cooled tomatoes onto the feta. Drizzle with hot honey and sprinkle of fresh thyme. Serve with pitas and enjoy!

Welcome back to Episode 29 of All Things Greek! My new Greek series where I share recipes from my childhood and summers spent in Greece as a kid.  Today we are making Banana-Nutella Crepes.  The iconic street food dessert of Greece (at least where I am from).

I made this recipe a bit smaller so everyone can enjoy it because the ones back home are HUGE! So, break out your skillet because you are going to love these Nutella crepes as much as I do.

A few recipes why I love this easy, delicious recipe!

1. Can be made sweet OR savoury!
2. Customizable! Not feeling Nutella, add peanut butter! Not feeling sweet, add cheese!
3. Quick – Between prep and cook time, you can whip up this Nutella crepe recipe in only 25 minutes.

Here’s everything you need to be teleported back to Greece for the last hints of summer! 

For the crepe batter:

	2 eggs, room temperature
	2 tbsp butter, melted and slightly cooled
	1 cup all purpose flour
	1/4 tsp salt
	1/2 tbsp sugar
	1 cup whole milk

Toppings:

	4-5 bananas (about 1/3 banana sliced, per crepe)
	1 cup @nutella or other chocolate spread (1-2 per crepe)
	6-8 digestif biscuit cookies (around half per crepe)

INSTRUCTIONS:

 
1. Whisk the eggs, melted butter, flour, salt and sugar to combine. Then, gradually whisk in the milk until all of the ingredients are well mixed together. Let the batter sit for 5 minutes. 
2. To a 8-10 inch nonstick skillet or crepe pan, melt ½-1 tablespoon of butter over medium-low heat, make sure it covers the bottom of the entire pan. Once the butter is melted, add a 1/4-1/3 cup of the batter, enough to evenly coat the pan, rotate the pan to help coat the bottom with the batter.

Welcome Back to Episode 35 of All things Greek! Today we are making Easy Greek Zucchini Fritters (Kolokithokeftedes). What a mouthful!  These easy zucchini fritters are the perfect snack, side dish, or appetizer. In a Greek household, these are called Kolokithokeftedes. “Kolokithi” means zucchini, and “Keftedes” means meatballs, so essentially when you combine the two, you get zucchini meatballs, or in this case, zucchini fritters. These are full of fresh herbs, and salty feta. They’re so good, and I promise you’re going to love them. 
 ❤️ Why You’ll Love Zucchini Fritters

Easy: These zucchini fritters are really easy to make (all you need in 1 bowl!). You can make them with a few simple ingredients in just 35 minutes! 
Flavorful: These fritters are popping with flavor with the fresh mint and dill. They’re so flavorful and delicious, that you won’t be able to eat just one - don’t forget the Tzatziki! 
Versatile: I love these on their own, but they are great as a side dish, snack, appetizer, or even to throw on top of a salad for a little bit of crunch. 

Ingredients:

3 medium zucchini, shredded / grated
salt
1/2 cup diced red onion
3 garlic cloves, minced
1 cup crumbled feta cheese
1/4 cup packed fresh chopped mint
1/4 cup packed fresh chopped dill
1/2 tsp salt
1/2 tsp pepper
2 eggs
1 1/4 cup all purpose flour
2 tsp baking powder

Welcome Back to Episode 42 of All Things Greek, today we are making Greek Stuffed Eggplant (Papoutsakia)!

This stuffed eggplant recipe is going to blow your mind. Technically it’s called Papoutsakia in Greece, and translated to “little shoes” because these eggplant halves are adorable when stuffed with the delicious meat and bechamel sauce. They are similar to Moussaka but they’re more eggplant-heavy and actually way easier to make.

The Greek recipe has 3 components.  The eggplant that gets stuffed with my mom’s Kima - “meat sauce”, you might remember this from episode 32 of All Things Greek - and then topped with a creamy, delicious bechemal sauce before being baked in the oven.

Welcome Back to Episode 45 of All Things Greek! Today we are making Κοτόπουλο με πατάτες λεμονάτο στο φούρνο - AKA Greek Baked Lemon Chicken and Potatoes.  I feel like I have to add that it is actually being made by a Greek person…

This recipe is knock-your-socks-off delicious and it’s so easy to make. Just add everything to the casserole dish and let it bake. The aroma that’ll fill your house will make your mouth water.

I have so many core, deep, happy memories related to this dish.  Wednesday nights at church with my Greek community.  We didn’t go to church on Sundays because our priest wasn’t from our city so every month we would gather on a random Wednesday night after service (he would travel 3 hours to be with us) and eat a beautiful meal.  Each mother in the Greek community would bring an authentic, comforting dish.  My mom was very busy raising us, driving us from sport to sport and working at our family restaurant - so this was always her go-to!  Don’t confuse the 10 minutes of effort with simplicity or laziness, this dish is truly remarkable.  

NOTE: The yellow mustard isn’t something my mother did when we were growing up. It’s completely OPTIONAL! This is a new trend among new-age Greeks BUT it is wonderful.  You must try.  I don’t want to hear you bashing it unless you give it a try. 

Here’s is everything you will need to make my family’s meal. 

Ingredients:

5 medium yellow-fleshed potatoes, cut into wedges then halved (about 1 1/2 - 2 inch pieces)
juice of 3 lemons
1/2 cup olive oil - straight from my family’s village made using our olives. 
10 garlic cloves, smashed skins removed 
bone-in chicken thighs
1 1/2 tbsp yellow mustard (optional) - I used @Frenchs
2 tsp salt - I used @diamondcrystalsalt
1 tsp pepper
1 1/2 tbsp dried oregano - I used @simplyorganic
2 1/2 tsp garlic powder - I used @simplyorganic fresh oregano for garnish

Welcome Back to Episode 47 of All Things Greek! Today we are making My Greek Shrimp and Orzo Pasta Bake!  It’s got lots of tomatoes, orzo, olives and delicious feta.  I am just in love with how easy this meal is! She’s perfect for meal prep for the week or to make when you just don’t have the time or the energy for something more intense or elaborate. You can whip this bake up in only 25 minutes with a few tasty ingredients, herbs, and spices.

Here’s everything you’ll need - just over 10 ingredients! 

Ingredients:

1 cup orzo
1 tbsp chicken stock paste - sub for veg stock paste 
2 cups water
1 tsp onion powder
1 tsp garlic powder
1 tsp salt
1/2 tsp pepper
2 tsp dried oregano
3 tbsp tomato paste
540 ml can of diced tomatoes
1/3 cup finely chopped castelvetrano olives
1 lb defrosted shrimp, peeled and deveined
2 tbsp olive oil
1/2 cup crumbled feta cheese
fresh oregano for garnish 
Instructions:

1. Preheat the oven to 375F. 
2. To a medium-sized baking dish mix together the orzo, chicken stock paste, water, onion powder, garlic powder, salt, pepper, dried oregano, tomato paste, diced tomatoes and olives. Stir everything together until well combined. 
3. Bake in the oven for 12-15 minutes or until the orzo is al dente. To the pan add the shrimp and stir. Drizzle over the olive oil and bake for another 5-7 minutes or until the shrimp are just done. Stir and serve topped with crumbled feta cheese and fresh oregano. 
Notes:

Serve this with one of our favourite Greek salads - Simple Homemade Greek Salad

Welcome Back to Episode 48 of All Things Greek! Today we are making Dolmades (also known as dolmathes). Making the sauce and pouring it over each serving satisfies my needs but if you are different simply pour over the whole pot.

So not only are you enjoying these pockets of love all week but you are also getting the freshest version of them! Not to mention you’re combating food waste, and preventing freezer burn and that’s a big win in my Greek heart!

Welcome Back to Episode 53 of All Things Greek! Today we are making Κοτόπουλο με πατάτες λεμονάτο στο φούρνο BUT WITH SOME VEGGIES TOO - AKA Greek Baked Lemon Chicken, Veggies and Potatoes.  Being made by a Greek Gal with AUTHENTIC GREEK parents! 

The concept here is very simple, everything stays the same… Just add everything to the casserole dish and let it bake. The aroma that’ll fill your house will make your mouth water. 

Growing up my mama was VERY busy, as I’ve shared before.  So, putting together a nourishing meal wasn’t always the easiest task especially since some Greek meals take a long time to cook or prep. So this meal was her GO TO!  We always had it with Chicken and Potatoes but SO many of you made it and requested some veggies I thought I’d create something that is the perfect, balanced meal.  Carbs, Protein, Fat and Fibre.  I know you are going to love this and I think it’s going to become your go to meal in a pinch.

PLEASE NOTE: The yellow mustard isn’t something my mother did when we were growing up. It’s completely OPTIONAL! This is a new trend among new-age Greeks BUT it is wonderful.  You must try.  I don’t want to hear you bashing it unless you give it a try. 

Here’s is everything you will need to make my family’s meal. 

INGREDIENTS:

	6x skin on bone in chicken thighs 
	3x medium yellow-fleshed potatoes, cut into wedges then halved (about 1 1/2 – 2 inch pieces)
	1x zucchini, cut into 1 ½ inch pieces 
	1x red pepper, cut into 2 inch pieces
	1x red onion, cut into wedges then halved (about 1 1/2 – 2 inch pieces) 
Sauce:  
juice of 2 lemons
2 tsp chicken stock paste
1/2 cup olive oil
10 garlic cloves smashed
1 1/2 tbsp yellow mustard
2 tsp salt
1 tsp pepper
1 1/2 tbsp dried oregano
2 1/2 tsp garlic powder
fresh oregano for garnish

Welcome Back To Episode 55 of All Things Greek.  A series where I share recipes from MY childhood and family and memories from summers spent growing up in Greece.  Today I’m making a bomb flavour combo that my mom used to  cook for us! Homemade Chicken Meatballs with a Butter Lemon Sauce.

Welcome Back to Episode 58 of All Things Greek! Today we are making every Greek’s Best Friend, SKORDALIA.  Otherwise known as Greek Garlic and Potato Dip! When I say Garlic I MEAN GARLIC and a lot of it! It’s perfect for this time of year! Skordo directly translates to garlic in Greek so you know you’re in for a wild ride with this dip! 

It is made with a thick base of potatoes and is flavored with garlic and a few other simple like salt, good quality olive oil and red wine vinegar.  It’s incredibly easy to make and you can make it with only a handful of ingredients so you can even whip it up with a few things in your pantry.

Skordalia is a very popular dish in Greek especially around the Holidays and Greek National Independence Day, usually served with batter-fried salted cod.  AKA Bakaliaros! 

Here’s everything you need to make this delicious dip! 

Ingredients:

4 medium russet potatoes, peeled and diced
6 medium garlic cloves, minced or pressed
1/2 cup olive oil
1/2 cup water
3 tbsp red wine vinegar
2 tsp salt
dash of cracked black pepper
extra olive oil, to garnish
fresh oregano, to garnish (optional: not traditional)

Continued in the comments…

Notes:

* This dish is a BIG hit with invited guests! 
* Serve the Skordalia with anything you wish! It is traditionally served with cod but you could try it with our Fluffy Greek Pita Bread Recipe or fresh vegetables.

Welcome Back to Episode 62 of All Things Greek. A series where I share recipes from my childhood and memories from Summers growing up in Greece. Today we are making a highly requested recipe…. Introducing Chicken and Orzo with Tomatoes - otherwise known as Kotopoulo Youvesti. It’s a delicious, creamy, one-pot meal that I grew up eating almost every week. It’s simply, packed with flavours and a very popular recipe for us Greeks. 

There wasn’t a day when we wouldn’t come home to a fully cooked meal from my mom after school. She had a busy schedule but having delicious Greek food on the table for us was always her number one priority. This is my mother’s recipe and I think you are going to love it. She uses chicken, orzo, beautiful spices and @mutti_canada Strained Tomatoes (Passata). Be prepared to have the most delicious-smelling home – I should also note you are going to become incredibly addicted to this meal.

My mom loves using @mutti_canada because it does not contain preservatives to maintain the flavour and texture of their products. They only use the finest 100% Italian tomatoes and their most flavourful parts. They are sun-ripened tomatoes, which are processed within 24 hours of harvest. Which truly makes a difference, especially when you are used to the quality of tomatoes from Europe. They’re so creamy, and gently sweet and have an intense tomato flavour but come out subtle in dishes. I love using the Strained Tomatoes (Passata) myself! They are perfect for short-cooking dishes, like sauces but also perfect for soups, stews and any recipe that calls for pureed tomatoes.

Here’s everything you need to become a Greek Chicken Orzo Queen!

Today we are making the The Best Greek Chicken Marinade - it’s about to become a staple in your household, so listen up! 

One of the best parts about Greek cuisine is the chicken and pork souvlaki. The translation of souvlaki literally means “meat on skewers”, but you’ll find it all over Greece and in Greek homes described as an actual meal that consists of warm pita, savory meat, fresh veggies like cucumbers and red onion, and tzatziki sauce. The best part about souvlaki is that it’s so easy to recreate at home and I’m going to show you how with this easy Greek chicken marinade.

Here’s everything you need to become a Greek Chicken Street Food Expert!

Ingredients:

1 tsp salt
1/2 tsp pepper
2 garlic cloves, minced
1 tbsp dried oregano
juice of half a lemon
2 tbsp mustard
1/2 cup plain greek yogurt
2 tbsp olive oil 
Instructions:

1. Make the marinade by whisking together salt, pepper, minced garlic, dried oregano, lemon juice, mustard, greek yogurt and olive oil. Make the marinade by whisking together salt, pepper, minced garlic, dried oregano, lemon juice, mustard, greek yogurt and olive oil. Use to marinate chicken, pork or beef. Our favourite way to use it is making our Greek Chicken Souvlaki! 
2. Make the marinade ahead of time and store in the fridge for up to 2 days.

Welcome Back to Episode 64 of All Things Greek! Today we are making a newer to me recipe, Greek Soutzoukakia (Greek Meatballs in Tomato Sauce). Pronounced, “soot-zoo-KAH-kee-ah”!

They are known for their oval, football-like shape.  Made from ground beef, stale bread, lots of garlic, aromatic spices and the star of the show - CUMIN! They are then cooked with a beautiful tomato sauce and can be served with fluffy rice, mashed potatoes, Lahanosalta, Maroulosalata, or even our Viral Greek Pita.  
This combination of flavours left my whole team and I speechless, it was just so special, warming and delightful.  Here is everything you need to bring this level of comfort to your own home!

Ingredients:

For the meatballs,

1 lb lean ground beef
3 thick slices bread, crust removed
3 garlic cloves, pressed
2 tsp salt @diamondcrystalsalt 
1 tsp cumin @simplyorganicfoods 
1/4 tsp pepper
1 egg
2 tbsp olive oil 
For the tomato sauce,

400 ml can of finely chopped tomatoes (polpa) @muttipomodorousa @mutti_canada 
1 tsp salt @diamondcrystalsalt 
1/4 tsp sugar
1/2 cup white wine
1/2 cup water
